duties: The Teaching Assistant will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP014 (Introduction to University Studies), a core course of the Transitional Year Program at University of Toronto. This course aims to help students develop and strengthen the academic and life skills required to succeed as university students. It will include presentations on and practice in time management, note taking, study skills, essay writing, and preparation for examinations. In addition, it will deal with important matters for supporting mature students such as financial aid and how to get it, balancing study with family obligations, paid labour and other life contingencies, effective use of major student services, and techniques for dealing with the stresses and complications of academic life. The Teaching Assistant (TA) will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the course. The TA will help to lead a classes that support TYP students in their development of academic and life skills, including note-taking, the writing process, research, organization, and other related skills. The TA will evaluate student work, provide feedback, schedule and hold office hours,  provide academic support for course assignments, and lead discussions, and manage the course Quercus. Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA will be required to attend  lectures, and occasional staff meetings. Please note, this course will be offered in person, with online elements (i.e. Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.

duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations written by students with documented disabilities who are registered with AccessAbility Services at the University of Toronto, Scarborough (UTSC). 
Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
•Supervising in-person tests and examinations written by persons wwith disability-related accommodations; some remote shifts may be required
• Through active invigilation, maintain the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
• Maintaining confidentiality and security of student and test/exam information
• Ensuring the provision of disability-related accommodations to students as authorized by AccessAbility Services
• Monitoring test/exam time allotments
• Handling student concerns/problems and referring to Test and Exam Coordinator where appropriate
• Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
• Preparing completed in-person tests/exams for return delivery 
• Verifying student identification
• Maintaining required administrative records
• Ensuring the physical exam space, including supply cabinet, Invigilator work station, and students' writing areas, are kept clean and organized

• Applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:30 AM - 10:30 PM, Monday through Saturday

• A minimum of 45 hours of availability must be provided during all final exam periods. N.B. Occasional Sunday shifts may also be required

• New Invigilators are required to participate in preliminary in-person independent shifts after completion of their shadow shifts
Please note that all aspects of training will be scheduled between 7:30 AM - 5:00 PM Monday through Saturday.
Successful candidates must attend three final exam meetings to be held the week before deferred and final exam period begins. The meetings will be scheduled between 8:30 AM – 5:00 PM, Mondays to Fridays.

duties:
As part of the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program, a writing-instruction initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead Writing TA (LWTA) will work with WIT staff and the WIT Unit Contact to support course instructors and TAs in selected courses, as well as support undergraduate student writing development overall in the hiring department.

The LWTA will perform the following duties:
• Participate in training sessions (with LWTAs from other units) in July and throughout the year (late August, early January, and an end-of-year event)
• Read book chapters, articles, etc. on writing education pedagogy
• Meet with WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts, and course instructors to plan writing assignments activities and for tutorials, labs, or lectures
• Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs on writing-related topics, such as providing feedback to students on critical reading, writing, planning tutorial/lab activities related to writing, etc.
• Develop and/or adapt resources on writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignments) for instructors, TAs, and students
• Communicate regularly by email and in person with course instructors, WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts and others to implement WIT activities
• Collaborate with LWTAs in other units by meeting in peer groups and sharing writing instruction resources
• Collect and analyze data on WIT (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, TA and instructor focus groups, etc.)
• Document activities (e.g., help draft unit WIT goals, provide monthly updates, write a final a report about WIT activities in the unit, etc.)

NOTE: The applicant must be available for approximately 25 hours of training and preparatory work (e.g., consultations with WIT coordinators, contacts, and course instructors) throughout July and August. Mandatory training sessions will be held online on July 15, July 16, and July 17, 2025; subsequent mandatory training sessions will be held in person on August 25, 2025, January 9, 2026, and March 30, 2026. All training sessions are held from 1:00 to 4:00 pm Eastern.

• As part of the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program, a writing-instruction initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead Writing TA (LWTA) will work with WIT staff and the WIT Unit Contact to support course instructors and TAs in selected courses, as well as support undergraduate student writing development overall in the hiring department. The LWTA will perform the following duties for ANT204H1S, ANT210H1S, ANT253H1F, ANT329H1S, ANT344H1F, ANT484H1F: Participate in training sessions (with LWTAs from other units) in July and throughout the year (late August, early January, and an end-of-year event)

• Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs on writing-related topics, such as providing feedback to students on critical reading, writing, planning tutorial/lab activities related to writing, etc.
• Develop and/or adapt resources on writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignments) for instructors, TAs, and students 
• Communicate regularly by email and in person with course instructors, WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts and others to implement WIT activities

• Collect and analyze data on WIT (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, TA and instructor focus groups, etc.)

Scholarly expertise relevant to the course material (as shown, for example, by dissertation research). The principal focus of this course is the complex engagement of literature and the arts with both colonial and neo-colonial encounters between, Europe, Africa and the Americas over the last five hundred years. Exploring world cultures through the prism of colonial encounters facilitates discussions about the genesis of contemporary politics of globalisation as well as the accompanying dynamics of exploitation and resistance. This approach will also help to elucidate the ways in which contact between different world zones have been pivotal in the development of new national and regional cultures. In the process we engage with a wide range of questions including environmental precarity, food security, cultural violence, religious alterity, revolutions, and the coming of age of new subjectivities.   The material to be discussed will be organized under four broad headings: The Columbian Exchange in Cinema and Art; Colonial Encounters and Latin American Politics of Identity; Fictions of Colonial Encounters in West Africa; Narratives of Colonial and Neo-Colonial Encounters in the Caribbean. 

Primary texts may include works by
Miguel de Cervantes, Juan Rulfo, Octaivo Paz, Carlos Fuentes, William Shakespeare, Joseph Conrad, Chinua Achebe, Chimamanda Ngozi Adiche, Ama Ata Aidoo, Derek Walcott, Earl Lovelace, Olive Senior, Jaime Manrique and Anthony Winkler.

Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following:
--Maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
--Maintaining confidentiality of student and test/exam information
--Ensuring the provision of accommodations to students as specified by Accessibility Services
--Monitoring test/exam time allotments
--Handling student concerns/problems and escalating to the Coordinator, Accommodated Testing Services, as needed.
--Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
--Preparing completed tests/exams for return delivery
--Maintaining required administrative records

Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled, therefore minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed. The test centre is open from 7:00 AM to 11:00 PM and applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:00 AM and 11:00 PM, Monday to Friday with a minimum of 10 hours of availability each week. --Ability to remain calm under pressure

application_procedure: Please submit a letter of interest, a curriculum vitae, a writing sample (individually written and no more than four pages), and the names of two referees who have supervised you in course TAships by May 23, 2025 via https://forms.office.com/r/wh9bXnN2JJ
duties: As part of the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program, a writing-instruction initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead Writing TA (LWTA) will work with WIT staff and the WIT Unit Contact to support course instructors and TAs in selected courses, as well as support undergraduate student writing development overall in the hiring department. The LWTA will perform the following duties: • Participate in training sessions (with LWTAs from other units) in July and throughout the year (late August, early January, and an end-of-year event); • Read book chapters, articles, etc. on writing pedagogy; • Meet with WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts, and course instructors to plan writing assignments activities and for tutorials, labs, or lectures; • Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs on writing-related topics, such as providing feedback to students on critical reading, writing, planning tutorial/lab activities related to writing, etc.; • Develop and/or adapt resources on writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignments) for instructors, TAs, and students; • Communicate regularly by email and in person with course instructors, WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts and others to implement WIT activities; • Collaborate with LWTAs in other units by meeting in peer groups and sharing writing instruction resources; • Collect and analyze data on WIT (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, TA and instructor focus groups, etc.); • Document activities (e.g., help draft unit WIT goals, provide monthly updates, write a final a report about WIT activities in the unit, etc.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: 1) Current PhD student with least two years' experience as a course TA, whether leading tutorials/ labs, in-class instruction, or grading; 2) Excellent oral communication and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with administrators, course instructors, and TAs; 3) Strong administrative skills, including ability to schedule meetings and training sessions, plan and document work; 4) Strong time management skills with ability to meet multiple deadlines; 5) Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops; 6) Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline; 7) Flexible schedule, willing and able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings with WIT staff, course instructors, and TAs. NOTE: The applicant must be available for approximately 25 hours of training and preparatory work (e.g., consultations with WIT coordinators, contacts, and course instructors) throughout July and August. Mandatory training sessions will be held online from July 23 to 25, 2024, and in-person on August 28, 2024. All training sessions are held from 1:00 to 4:00 pm Eastern.
qualifications_preferred: Doctoral candidate in the Department for the Study of Religion is preferred, along with previous experience as a WIT TA in any RLG course.
salery: July 1 – December 31, 2025: $52.97/hour; January 1 – April 30, 2026: $53.92/hour + vacation pay
